metadata.title: Exploring the interactions between engineered nanomaterials and immune cells at 3D nano-bio interfaces to discover potent nano-adjuvants

sections.text:
Engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) as adjuvants can potentiate the adaptive immune responses to antigens by activating immune cells in three dimensional (3D) matrixes of tissues. However, few reports explored the interactions of nano-adjuvants and immune cells at 3D nanobio interfaces. Herein we designed an alginate-calcium microsphere of macrophage cells to explore the interactions. By an extensive comparison of ENM-induced cytokines in 2D and 3D cultured cells, IL-1β released in 3D microspheres was found to be a predictive biomarker to assess ENM-induced immune responses in vivo. Among nine representative ENMs, La2O3 boosts the highest adaptive humoral immune response, even stronger than clinically used Alum adjuvant. It could be attributed to the biotransformation of La2O3 from spherical particles into urchin-like LaPO4, resulting in strong biopersistence and NLRP3 inflammasome activation. These findings could be potentially used for the high throughput screening of nano-adjuvants from increasingly invented ENMs to speed up their clinical uses. © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Key words: Adjuvant; 3D culture; Inflammation; Structure–activity relationship; Transformation
Vaccine adjuvants, as important components for vaccination, could facilitate the living organisms to generate desired immune responses to antigens. Recently, nano-adjuvants have aroused massive research enthusiasms because they exhibit
☆ Acknowledgments: This work was supported by the grant from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 31671032, No. 21806116), Key Project of social development of Jiangsu Province (BE2018653), Suzhou Science and Technology Development Project (No. SYS201715), Key Project of Natural Science Foundation of the Higher Education Institutions of Jiangsu Province (17KJA310003) and a project funded by the Priority Academic Program Development of Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions (PAPD).
☆☆ Conflict of interest: The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2019.102037 1549-9634/© 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
strong immune cell recruitment activity,1–3 high loading capability and prolonged release of antigens,4 compared to traditional vaccine adjuvants, such as Alum, oil emulsions and chitosan.5,6 Substantial immune-boosting effects have been discovered in several ENMs including graphene oxide (GO),7 metal oxides (MOx),8 carbon nanotubes (CNTs),9,10 and cellulose nanofibers (CNFs).11 While the physicochemical properties of ENMs were found to impact their immune activities,12,13 the interactions between adjuvants and immune cells in 3D matrixes of tissues or organs play important roles for enhancing adaptive humoral immune effects to antigens,14 which demand extensive explorations at 3D nano-immune cell interfaces.
Recently, the development of globalization has sped up the spreading of some lethal microbes (Ebola virus, avian influenza, etc.),15 which necessitates rapid explorations of potent vaccines as well as accompanied adjuvants. Immune therapy as a
promising treatment to cure cancer also requires novel potent adjuvants to facilitate the production of cytotoxic T cells.16 These crises in human health demand in vitro rapid screenings of nano-adjuvants to replace expensive, time- and laborconsuming animal tests. Some attempts have been made to unearth the contributions of ENM-induced immune cytokine release in vaccine inoculation.17,18 THP-1 cell, a monocytic cell line, which could differentiate into macrophage-like cell with M1 or M2 phenotype, is popularly used to examine the immune responses of ENMs.19 Sun et al have found a close connection between the adjuvant effects of AlOH nanoparticles and their IL-1β generation in THP-1 cells.20 Kenichi et al showed that gold nanoparticles could induce significant IL-1β, IL-6 and TNF-α production in RAW264.7 cells.21 Steven et al summarized some putative cytokines (IL-1β, IL-18 and IL-33) that were involved in the action mechanisms of Al.22 However, all these efforts were made in 2D cultured immune cells, and failed to simulate the 3D biological matrixes of tissues or organs.14 Currently, few attempts have been made to explore the interactions between nano-adjuvants and immune cells at 3D nano-bio interfaces.
Alginate-calcium (Alg-Ca) microspheres are popularly used for 3D cell culture because of their advantages in mimicking the cell growth environment in real tissues, including the good biocompatibility and fabricability as well as the tissue-like stiffness.23,24 We hypothesized that 3D nano-immune cell interactions could be explored by examining the behaviors of ENMs in Alg-Ca microspheres of THP-1 cells. We deliberately selected nine ENMs to compare their immune activities with a clinically used adjuvant, Al. Six immunological cytokines (IL1β, IL-6, IL-12, TNF-α, IL-2 and IFN-γ) were examined in 2D or 3D cultured THP-1 cells to evaluate the immune activity rankings of ENMs. We deciphered the detailed interaction mechanism of a potent nano-adjuvant, La2O3 at 3D nano-bio interfaces. Animal experiments were further performed to validate the in vitro results.

sections.heading: Reagents and materials
sections.text: We purchased Al from Thermo Scientific (Waltham, USA) and Hoechst 33342 from InvivoGen (San Diego, USA). Immunoglobulin G1 (IgG1), Immunoglobulin E (IgE), IL-1β, IL-6, IL-12, TNF-α, IFN-γ and IL-2 ELISA Kits were obtained from BD Biosciences (San Jose, USA). CD 206 antibody was purchased from Bioss (Beijing, China). 1,3,4,6-tetrachloro-3A, 6A-diphenylglycouril, lipopolysaccharides (LPS), N-(3Dimethylam- inopropyl)-N′-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloridecommercial grade (EDC), Phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA), sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) and polyetherimide (PEI) were from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, USA). MTS kit was from Promega (Madison, USA). Ovalbumin (OVA) was from R&D (Minneapolis, USA). Magic Red reagent was purchased from Immunochemistry Technologies (Bloomington, USA). 125I was from GMS Pharmaceutical Corporation (Shanghai, China).

sections.heading: Preparation and collection of ENMs
sections.text:
Nanofibers including CNF-1, CNF-2 and CNF-3 were prepared by an ultrasound-assisted TEMPO oxidation method.25 A uniform fiber suspension pulp about 1% concentration was prepared with the commercial softwood pulp (Catalyst Paper Corporation, Canada) before oxidation treatment. TEMPO (16 mg), NaBr (100 mg) and various amount of NaClO (150 mg, 375 mg and 600 mg) were added into three sets of 1% softwood pulps (1 g) and adjust pH to 10. After oxidation at 25 °C for 60 min, the resulted fibers were washed with ultrapure water to neutrality, and homogenized at 80 MPa for five times with a high-pressure homogenizer (AH08–100, ATS Engineering Inc., Canada) to obtain nanofibers with different lengths.
Pristine CNTs purchased from Cheap Tubes Inc. (Brattleboro, USA) were used to synthesize carboxyl and polyethylenimine (PEI) functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes (COOHCNTs, PEI-CNTs) according to a previous report.26 To synthesize COOH-CNTs, pristine CNTs (1 g) was dispersed in 120 mL of concentrated H2SO4 and HNO3 (3:1, v/v) solution and reacted for 30 min at 120 °C. After cooling to room temperature, the solutions were diluted with 10-fold deionized water (DI H2O), filtered through a 0.45 μm membrane and washed to collect COOH-CNTs. PEI-CNTs were prepared by reacting acylation of COOH-CNTs with PEI in dimethylformamide (DMF). In brief, COOH-CNTs (100 mg) were dispersed in 50 mL DMF by water-bath sonication for 5 min. 20 mL SOCl2 was gradually dropped into the COOH-CNTs solution in icewater bath and refluxed for 24 h. The pellets were collected by centrifugation, washed with hydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF), and resuspended in 50 mL DMF to react with PEI for 3 days. The resulted PEI-CNTs were dispersed in DI H2O after sufficient washing. CeO2-1 and CeO2-2 were prepared based on a hydrothermal synthesis method, and the length of CeO2 was controlled by tuning the initial concentrations of cerium (III) chloride (CeCl3).
27 La2O3 was prepared based on a reported method with little modifications.28 In detail, 0.217 g La (NO3)3·6H2O and 0.192 g citric acid were dissolved in 20 mL DI H2O to react with 20 mL 10% KOH under vigorously stirring. The mixture was reacted at 180 °C for 15 h under magnetic stirring to form La(OH)3, which was collected by centrifugation (5000 rpm, 30 min) and washed three times with DI H2O. La2O3 nanoparticles were obtained by a 400 °C calcination treatment for 4 h. TiO2 was obtained from Nanostructured & Amorphous Materials (Houston, TX, USA).

sections.heading: Characterization of ENMs
sections.text: The morphology of ENMs was observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Tecnai G20, FEI, USA) at a voltage of 120 kV and atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Nanoscope Icon, Veeco, USA). Drops of ENM DI H2O solution (50 μg/mL) were placed on a grid and mica plate and dried at room temperature for TEM and AFM observations, respectively. Zeta potentials and particle sizes of ENMs in water or cell culture medium were measured by dynamic light scattering (Zetasizer Nano ZS90, Malvern, UK).

sections.heading: 2D and 3D culture of THP-1 cells
sections.text:
THP-1 cells, NLRP3 deficient (NLRP3−/−) THP-1 cells and ASC deficient (ASC−/−) THP-1 cells were grown in RPMI-1640 cell culture medium supplemented with 10% FBS, 100 U/mL of penicillin and 100 μg/mL of streptomycin at 5% CO2, 37 °C. NLRP3−/− and ASC−/− THP-1 cells were established at UCLA CURE Integrated Molecular Technologies Core. Before exposure of ENMs to 2D cultured THP-1 cells, aliquots of 100 μL cell (3 × 104 cells/well) suspensions were primed by 1.0 μg/mL PMA and seeded into 96-well plates for incubation overnight. The fabrication of 3D Alg-Ca microcapsule was based on the method described in the previous study with a slight modification.29 First, 1.5% (w/v) sodium alginate solutions containing 10 μg/mL PMA and 100 ng/mL LPS were mixed with THP-1 cells (3 × 106 cells/mL). Then the mixture was extruded into CaCl2 solution (0.1 M) through a 0.5 mm needle with an electrostatic droplet generator (Bio-leader Incorp, China). After 30 min gelling in CaCl2 solution, the 3D microspheres encapsulated with THP-1 cells were collected by removing the gelling solution and washed twice with cell culture medium. 1 mL 3D microspheres were added into 9 mL of RPMI-1640 media to be seeded into 96- well plates (around 700 microspheres /well) for ELISA and toxicity tests.
Exposure of ENMs to 2D or 3D cultured THP-1 cells
All nine ENM samples were dispersed in DI H2O to prepare stock solutions (5 mg/mL) by a probe sonicator (Scientz-IID, Scientz, China) at 32 W for 10 s. Appropriate amounts of each stock solution were added to medium containing 10 ng/mL LPS to obtain the desired final concentration before exposure to THP1 cells. To incubate with 2D cultured THP-1 cells, aliquots of ENM suspensions (120 μL) were added to the primed THP-1 cells in 96 well plates for 24 h incubation. For exposure of ENMs to 3D cultured THP-1 cells, ENMs suspensions containing 1.5% (w/v) sodium alginate, 10 μg/mL PMA and 100 ng/mL LPS were mixed with THP-1 cells (3 × 106 cells/ mL) to prepare microspheres by electrostatic droplet generator. THP-1 cell microspheres encapsulating varied amounts of ENMs were seeded in 96-well plates (around 700 microspheres /well) for 48 h incubation.

sections.heading: ELISA and cytotoxicity test
sections.text:
THP-1 cells were incubated with ENMs at 0-200 μg/mL for 0-48 h. The supernatants were collected to detect the expression of various cytokines using ELISA kits. Meanwhile, aliquots of 120 μL diluted MTS solutions were added to 96-well plates containing cell pellets or 3D microspheres, and incubated at 37 °C for 3 h. Then centrifugation (3000 rpm, 5 min) was performed to transfer the supernatants (100 μL/well) into new plates for absorbance detection at OD 490 nm by a Microplate Reader (Synergy NEO HTS, Biotek, USA).
Fluorescent or radiological labeling of ENMs
Fluorescein isothiocyanate conjugated with bovine serum albumin (FITC-BSA) was used to label ENMs by an amidation
reaction.30 In detail, 10 mg of EDC and 20 mg of NHS were added into 4 mL of ENMs (100 μg/mL) in DI H2O and stirred for 2 h at 25 °C. Then ENM pellets were obtained by centrifugation (20,000 rpm, 10 min) to react with 1 mL of FITC-BSA solution (0.1 mg/mL) under magnetic stirring. After 2 h reaction, FITC-BSA labeled ENMs were washed three times with DI H2O to remove non-covalent bound FITC-BSA, and suspended in 400 μL DI H2O.
In order to visualize the retention of ENMs in animals, we synthesized 125I labeled ENMs (125I-ENMs) via a standard activator oxidation method.31 The radiolabeling experiments were performed in a radioactivity laboratory of the State Key Laboratory of Radiation Medicine and Protection, China. Briefly, 1,3,4,6-tetrachloro-3A,6A-diphenylglycouril (0.5 mg) in 1 mL of trichloromethane was dried under N2 blowing before they reacted with 500 μL ENM suspensions (1.65 mg/mL in DI H2O) and 1 mCi of
125I at 37 °C for 30 min. The reaction solutions were added into ultrafiltration tubes with molecular weight cut-off at 10 kDa to separate 125I-ENMs at 3000 rpm for 30 min, and washed with DI H2O to remove free
125I agents. The resulted 125I-ENMs were suspended in 500 μL DI H2O for radiological imaging.
Characterization of transformed ENMs in PSF and cells
Abiotic phagolysosomal simulated fluids (PSF) buffer was prepared according to established a recipe,32 which consisted of 6.65 g/L NaCl, 142 mg/L Na2HPO4, 29 mg/L CaCl2·H2O, 62 mg/L Na2SO4, 8.09 g/L potassium phthalate and 250 mg/L glycine at pH 4.5. 500 μg of ENMs was suspended in 10 mL PSF buffer and probe sonicated for 15 s at 32 W. The ENM pellets were centrifuged (15,000 rpm, 10 min) and washed twice with DI H2O, after PSF treatment for 24 h at 37 °C. Then TEM was performed to characterize their morphology. To visualize intracellular ENMs, the THP-1 cells incubated with 50 μg/mL ENMs for 12 h were washed twice with PBS and fixed with 2% glutaraldehyde in PBS for 30 min, followed by overnight incubation at 4 °C. The cells were fixed by incubation with 1% osmium tetroxide for 1 h, and subjected to gradient dehydration in ethanol. Then the THP-1 cells were embedded in Epon after propylene oxide treatment. Finally, we used a Reichert-Jung Ultracut E ultramicrotome to cut sections with 50- 70 nm thickness and place on copper grids. Cell structures were observed by TEM after staining with uranyl acetate and Reynolds lead citrate.

sections.heading: Confocal imaging
sections.text:
To determine the distribution of ENMs in cells, FITC-BSA labeled ENMs (50 μg/mL) were exposed to 3D THP-1 cell microspheres for 0 or 48 h. Then the microspheres were stained with Hoechst 33344 (100 ng/mL) for 30 min, and washed with PBS. For cathepsin B imaging in cells, THP-1 cells were seeded in an eight-well chamber (1 × 106 cells/well) and primed by PMA (1 μg/mL) for 16 h. Then the cells were incubated with ENMs (50 μg/mL) for 6 h, washed twice with PBS and stained with Magic Red for 1 h, Hoechst 33342 for 30 min. After twice washing with PBS, 4% paraformaldehyde was used to fix cells.
All the cell samples were observed by a confocal microscope (UltraView VoX, PerkinElmer, USA).
Animal vaccination using ENMs and OVA
Eight week-old female C57BL/6 mice, obtained from Nanjing Peng Sheng Biological Technology (Nanjing, Jiangsu, China), were housed in a standard laboratory conditions by Soochow University guidelines for care and treatment of laboratory animals. The animal experiment was carried out under the supervision of Institutional Animal Ethical Committee (IAEC) of Soochow University. To verify the humoral immune response induced by the mixture of ENMs and OVA, we designed a vaccination program for animals which were vaccinated with OVA/ENMs (400 μg/500 μg) via intraperitoneal injection on day 1 and performed a booster vaccination injection with OVA (200 μg) on day 7. The blood samples were collected from anesthetized animals at 14-day post injection. The serum was separated from the blood samples by centrifugation (3000 rpm, 10 min) for IgG1 and IgE detection by ELISA kits.
Single-photon emission computed tomography/computed tomography (SPECT/CT) imaging studies
Eight week-old female C57BL/6 mice were injected via i.p. with 300 μCi of 125I-ENMs for the imaging study, which was performed on day 1, day 5 and day 14 by the SPECT/CT (MILabs, Utrecht, the Netherlands) with an extra ultra-high sensitivity collimator (54 pinholes, reconstructed resolution 1.0 mm, sensitivity ≫12,500 cps/MBq).33 A software package was used to reconstruct SPECT/CT images.

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text: The R values of correlation coefficients between released cytokines and IgG1/IgE expressions were calculated by one-way ANOVA analysis. The heatmap was completed by the software “Heatmap Illustrator”. All of the results were shown by mean ± SD. Statistical significance was evaluated using one-way ANOVA or two-tailed Student's t test.

sections.heading: Characterization of ENMs
sections.text:
For an extensive screening of nano-adjuvants, we collected nine representative ENMs with different compositions, shapes, sizes and surface charges, including metal oxides (CeO2-1, CeO2-2, La2O3, TiO2), cellulose nanofibers (CNF-1, CNF-2, CNF-3), carboxyl and polyethylenimine functionalized multiwalled carbon nanotubes (COOH-CNTs, PEI-CNTs). We first detected the endotoxin levels of all collected ENMs. As shown in Figure S1, the endotoxin levels in nine materials are less than 0.2 EU/mL, which is significantly lower than the threshold (0.5 EU/ mL) of sterile water. After that, the physicochemical properties of these particles were characterized by TEM, AFM, Zetapotential and dynamic light scattering analyzer. TEM images show that La2O3 and TiO2 have spherical morphologies with primary sizes at 20-50 nm; CeO2 and CNTs exhibit rod or fiber
shapes (Figure 1, A). While the lengths of CeO2-1 and CeO2-2 are at 50-100 nm and 450-650 nm, respectively, PEI-CNTs and COOH-CNTs have similar lengths at 200-450 nm. Due to the low electron density of CNFs, we used AFM to visualize their morphologies. As shown in Figure 1, B, CNFs exhibit fiber morphologies with similar diameters (10-20 nm) but different lengths at 200-300 nm (CNF-1), 600-900 nm (CNF-2), and 1500-1800 nm (CNF-3). The surface charges and hydrodynamic sizes of ENMs were determined in DI H2O and cell culture medium (Table S1). La2O3, CeO2 and PEI-CNTs exhibit positive charges with Zeta potential at +15-+50 mV. CNFs, TiO2 and COOH-CNTs show negative charges (−47 to −26 mV). However, all these ENMs have similar surface charges (−15 to −6 mV) after dispersion in cell culture media due to the formation of protein corona.25,26 Compared to their pristine sizes, all these particles show a little agglomeration in DI H2O and cell culture medium.
Cytokine production in 2D or 3D cultured THP-1 cells
Firstly, we demonstrated the successful differentiation of THP-1 cell into macrophage-like cells by comparing the cell morphology changes and CD 206 expressions before and after PMA treatments (Figure S2). Then the immune responses of ENMs were detected in 2D or 3D cultured THP-1 cells. We attempted to design 3D Alg-Ca microspheres to encapsulate THP-1 cells and mimic the 3D biological matrixes of tissues or organs during vaccination. THP-1 cell microspheres were prepared by extruding the mixture of alginate and cell suspensions into calcium chloride under a high electrostatic field (Figure S3). First, the cytotoxicity of ENMs was assessed by detecting the viability of THP-1 cells after ENM exposures. MnO2 nanoparticles were used as a positive control. All nine ENMs show little effects on the proliferation of 2D and 3D cultured THP-1 cells (Figure S4), suggesting that these particles have good biocompatibility. Next, we compared the immune responses of ENMs in THP-1 cells by examining cytokine productions. Al was used as a positive control. As shown in Figure 2, A, after exposure to ENMs, substantial dose-dependent IL-1β is detected in 2D and 3D cultured THP-1 cells. We compared the immune activity rankings of nine ENMs based on IL-1β levels (Figure 2, B). Three ENMs show similar rankings in 2D and 3D models: La2O3 has the highest ranking; PEI-CNTs ranks No. 2; CeO2-1 exhibits low immune activity. However, most ENMs including CNF-1, CNF-2, CNF-3, COOH-CNTs TiO2 and CeO2-2 show inconsistent rankings in two culture models. CNF-1 induces higher IL-1β production than CNF-2 and CNF-3 in 2D model, but they show an opposite trend in 3D microspheres. While CeO2-2 and TiO2 rank No. 3 and No. 5 in 2D model, respectively, their rankings switch to No. 7 and No. 9 in 3D microspheres. These results indicate that the spatial dimensions of biological models may significantly impact the immune responses of ENMs. We further examined other cytokines in both culture models, including TNF-α, IL-6, IFNγ, IL-12 and IL-2 (Table 1). Most ENMs except for TiO2 induced massive TNF-α production and slight increase of IL-6 in 2D and 3D cultured THP-1 cells, but all nine materials have limited effects on IFN-γ, IL-12 and IL-2 productions. Similar to the IL-
1β release profile, the productions of TNF-α and IL-6 gradually grow along with the increased exposure doses of ENMs in THP1 cells (Figure S5).
ENM-induced humoral immune responses in vivo and the correlations to cytokines in vitro
Since some ENMs (CNF-1, CNF-2, CNF-3, COOH-CNTs, CeO2-2 and TiO2) show distinct cytokine releases in 2D and 3D cultured THP-1 cells, it's hard to make predictions for their immune responses in vivo. To examine the in vitro results, we assessed the immune activities of ENMs in C57BL/6 mice by detecting antibody expressions after intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection of ENM-antigen components. Endotoxin-free OVA was used as the antigen. IgG1 and IgE expressions were checked in serum to evaluate the humoral immune responses. We began with a dose response study, in which animals were injected by CNF-1 and OVA components at different ratios. The vaccination process included a prime on day 1 and a booster inoculation on day 7 (Figure S6). Two weeks after initial inoculation, mouse serum was collected to detect the productions of IgG1 and IgE
by ELISA. As shown in Figure S6, IgG1 and IgE show dosedependent release profiles and get to a plateau at a high CNF-1/ OVA ratio (500 μg/400 μg). Thus we selected this dose for vaccine inoculation of different ENM-OVA components. All nine samples were intraperitoneally injected into animals to compare their adaptive humoral immune effects. As shown in Figure 3, A, compared to OVA, six ENMs stimulate significant IgG1 and IgE productions. CeO2-1, CeO2-2 and CNF-3 have no effects on IgG1 expression. TiO2 shows little effects on two antibodies. Interestingly, among all these ENMs, La2O3 shows the highest adjuvant effects, even stronger than clinically used Al. Consistently, intramuscularly (i.m.) injected La2O3/OVA could also burst high expressions of IgG1 and IgE, similar to the levels in i.p. injection (Table S2).
In order to find appropriate cytokines as predictive indexes for nano-adjuvant screening, we calculated the correlation coefficients (R values) of IgG1 and IgE productions with different cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α, IL-6) induced by ENMs in 2D or 3D cultured THP-1 cells. We integrated the R values of different cytokines in heat maps (Figure 3, B). In the visual data display, the red indicates high correlations between in vitro
A
cytokine release and in vivo antibody production, and the green represents poor correlations. Among all comparisons, IL-1β in 3D microspheres shows the best correlations with IgG1 or IgE in a wide range of ENM exposure doses. These results suggest that IL-1β release in 3Dmicrospheres of THP-1 cells could be used as a predictive index to explore potent ENM adjuvants.
Assessments of biopersistence and NLRP3 inflammasome activation
To decipher the detailed mechanisms involved in the IL-1β production of ENMs, we first examined the biodistributions of three representative ENMs, La2O3, COOH-CNTs and CeO2-1 in
THP-1 cells. TEM images show all three particles could be internalized into lysosomes with vesicular structure. COOHCNTs and CeO2-1 preserved their pristine morphologies in the acidic, enzymatic compartment (Figure 4, A). Interestingly, La2O3 spheres transformed to “sea-urchin” structures with dramatic morphology changes. This biotransformation process could also be validated in PSF. We demonstrated that La2O3 particles could transform into LaPO4 including three dynamic transformation stages: whisker initiation, whisker growth, and mature of “sea-urchin” structure (Figure S7). The biotransformation of La2O3 may lead to lysosome damages, which are examined by a fluorescent substrate of lysosomal enzyme (cathepsin B) to stain the cells (Figure 4, B). While punctate distribution of red fluorescence indicating intact lysosomes was observed in untreated cells, La2O3 treated cells show severe lysosome damages with strong diffused fluorescence. COOHCNTs and CeO2-1 have a little effect. The released cathepsin B could induce the recruitment of NLRP3 inflammasome subunits including apoptosis associated speck-like protein containing CARD (ASC), NLRP3 and pro-caspase1 to assist the mature of IL-1β. NLRP3 inflammasome activation was further confirmed by using NLRP3- and ASC- gene knockdown THP-1 cells. As a consequence, their IL-1β productions remarkably decreased when compared to the wild type THP-1 cells treated with ENMs (Figure 4, B), suggesting that NLRP3 inflammasome activation was responsible for the production of IL-1β by La2O3.
Since biopersistence of adjuvants may contribute in their immune activities, the retention of ENMs was assessed in microspheres and animals. We speculated that the needles on “sea-urchin” LaPO4 structures may puncture the cellular components, and induce strong biopersistence in 3D biological matrixes. To demonstrate this, we used FITC-BSA to label ENMs and visualize their retentions in 3D microspheres. As shown in Figure 4, C, La2O3, CeO2-1 and COOH-CNTs show bright green dots and homogeneous distributions after they are encapsulated into 3D microspheres of THP-1 cells. CeO2-1 shows a significant decrease of green dot numbers at 48 h compared to their initial encapsulating density, suggesting a weak biopersistence of CeO2-1 in 3D microspheres. In contrast, La2O3 and COOH-CNTs exhibit strong biopersistences with limited reductions of green dots in 3D microspheres at 48 h. As shown in Figure S8, a majority of La2O3 nanoparticles are
internalized into cells (red arrows), surrounding the nuclei (blue), whereas a small portion of particles show intercellular distributions (yellow arrows). To further validate the retentions of ENMs, we prepared 125I-ENMs to visualize their distribution in vivo after intraperitoneal injection. As shown in Figure 4, D, although all three labeled ENMs show time-dependent clearance in animals during 14-day exposure, there are significant intermaterial differences. Consistent with the confocal images of 3D microspheres, La2O3 and COOH-CNTs exhibit strong biopersistence in animals, but CeO2-1 can be quickly cleared. These results demonstrated that Alg-Ca microspheres could well simulate the biological matrixes in real tissues to investigate the interactions of ENM-immune cells at 3D nano-bio interfaces. NLRP3 inflammasome activation and biopersistence of ENMs may coordinate to contribute in adaptive immune responses. Given that nanotoxicity is a huge hindrance for the biomedical applications of ENMs, we performed a systematic toxicity test of La2O3 in mice by i.p. injection. After 14-day exposure, we collected the blood and tissue organs of animals for safety examination. Limited pathological changes were observed in hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained images of heart, liver, spleen, kidney and lung (Figure S9). Consistently, blood tests also show negligible hazard effects.

sections.heading: Discussions
sections.text:
Currently, more and more studies have demonstrated that the biological activities of ENMs have close relationships with some of their physicochemical properties, a.k.a. structure–activity relationships (SARs).34–38 In our study, nine representative ENMs including different compositions (La2O3 and TiO2), surface charges (COOH-CNTs and PEI-CNTs), and sizes (CeO21, CeO2-2; CNF-1, CNF-2 and CNF-3) were found to induce different immune responses. From the perspective of SARs, the biotransformation capability of ENMs determined by particle compositions is the dominant factor responsible for immune responses. In detail, the phosphate affinity of La2O3 surfaces was found to dominate the particle transformation in lysosomes, cathepsin B release, NLRP3 inflammasome activation as well as subsequent IL-1β production in THP-1 cells. In animals, La2O3 bursts the highest adjuvant effects, even stronger than clinically
used Alum, suggesting that La2O3 may deserve more explorations in preclinical studies as an alternative of Alum. In detail, La2O3 particles were internalized into lysosomes of macrophage
cells for digestion in the acidic context. The released La ions (III) are able to bind by bystander phosphates resulting in the crystallization of hexagonal urchin-shaped LaPO4. This
biotransformation process leads to lysosomal damage, cathepsin B release, NLRP3 inflammasome activation and IL-1β release. Meanwhile, the “sea-urchin” LaPO4 structures may form a big obstruction for cellular clearance, leading to strong retention of nanoparticles in 3D bio-contexts. This may induce sustained immune stimulation in animals. Surface charges and aspect ratios also have impacts on the immune activities of ENMs. Positive charged CNTs and high aspect ratio materials may elicit stronger immune responses. Therefore, potent nano-adjuvants should be designed to have biotransformation capability, positive surface charges and rod/fiber shapes.,
The role of NLRP3 inflammasome in adjuvant effects is still debatable. Eisenbarth et al showed that Alum failed to boost IgG1 antibody responses in NLRP3KOmice.39 AndKool et al found that the number of Alum-induced inflammatory cells in the peritoneal cavity is decreased in NLRP3 deficient mice.40 In contrast, Franchi et al claimed that the NLRP3 inflammasome is critical for Alummediated IL-1β secretion but dispensable for adjuvant activity.41 Recently, some studies show that themechanisms of adjuvant effects are very comprehensive including the cross-talks among different immune cells including dendritic cells, T helper cells, and macrophages, as well as contributions from diverse cytokines such as IL-6, TNF-α, and IFN-γ and so on.42 Despite the debatable claims on the role of NLRP3 inflammasomes, most reports coincidentally show that the adaptive immune responses of Alum and ENMs are accompanied by inflammatory cytokine productions such as IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α, IFN-γ, etc.2,21 We speculated that these cytokines could be exploited for predictive screening of the adaptive immune responses of ENMs in vivo, which may significantly reduce the animal, labor and time costs in nano-adjuvant development. Since the biopersistence of nanoparticles is also reported to play an important role in ENM-induced immune responses,43 we deliberately examined the production of IL-6, TNF-α and IL-1β in 2D and 3D cultured THP-1 cells, and calculated their correlation coefficients with IgG1 and IgE expressions in vivo. Notably, IL-1β production in 3D THP-1 microspheres could well predict the ranks of adaptive immune responses of nine ENMs.
In short, we designed Alg-Ca microspheres of THP-1 cells to explore the interactions between ENMs and immune cells at 3D nano-bio interfaces. Among the nine representative ENMs, most of them induced significant IL-1β, TNF-α and IL-6 productions. And IL-1β in THP-1 cell microspheres could be used as a predictive index to evaluate the adjuvant effects of ENMs. Interestingly, La2O3 particles with strong biopersistence at 3D nano-bio interfaces induce the highest IL-1β production via NLRP3 inflammasome activation. These in vitro findings on 3D microspheres could be well validated in vivo by examining adaptive immune responses and visualizing ENM retentions. We believe our findings have significant implications for the exploration of nano-adjuvants in clinic to prevent microbial infection diseases and facilitate the development of cancer immune therapy.

sections.heading: Ethical conduct of research
sections.text:
The animals were housed in a standard laboratory conditions by Soochow University guidelines for care and treatment of
laboratory animals. The animal experiment was carried out under the supervision of IAEC of Soochow University.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2019.102037.

metadata.abstractText: Engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) as adjuvants can potentiate the adaptive immune responses to antigens by activating immune cells in three dimensional (3D) matrixes of tissues. However, few reports explored the interactions of nano-adjuvants and immune cells at 3D nanobio interfaces. Herein we designed an alginate-calcium microsphere of macrophage cells to explore the interactions. By an extensive comparison of ENM-induced cytokines in 2D and 3D cultured cells, IL-1β released in 3D microspheres was found to be a predictive biomarker to assess ENM-induced immune responses in vivo. Among nine representative ENMs, La2O3 boosts the highest adaptive humoral immune response, even stronger than clinically used Alum adjuvant. It could be attributed to the biotransformation of La2O3 from spherical particles into urchin-like LaPO4, resulting in strong biopersistence and NLRP3 inflammasome activation. These findings could be potentially used for the high throughput screening of nano-adjuvants from increasingly invented ENMs to speed up their clinical uses. © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
